Build Failed 

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/77642/ : FAILURE
any idea why do we need base64 encoding support for system dump which does not require for bmc dump?

Base64 was chosen to avoid the case where injected binary code is downloaded in a browser.

bmc dump I suspect has the same issue.
yes, but this patch set not going to use base64 encoding for bmc-dump. That will be a backward compatibility issue. Clients using the bmc-dump may not be expecting base64 encoding.
Done

Please don't use features from the details namespace.  It is not part of the public api.  Either use the existing base64 functions we already have, or work with the boost maintainers to make this part of the supported API.  I'm happy to have a discussion around this, because the base64 code seems to be well supported, but we need to start with a discussion with the boost maintainers (Vinnie).
Ack
please call this bmcweb.
Ack
We don't use this pattern of renaming namespaces.  You likely copied this from a boost example.  Please just inline the namespaces for searchability.
Ack
magic numbers.  Boost has functions for doing this calculation.  Please use them.
I could see same majic number usage in utility.hpp. What is the boost public function for this?
There isn't a boost public function for this (it's in details), but it's called encoded_size()
that means we should keep the magic number right?
Please prefer composition over inheritance in this case.  That makes it explicit which methods are supported, and ensures that they are all correct, not just the overridden ones.
Why * 2?
no need for either of these to be templates.  The writer will always be used with responses, and we don't ever customize the Fields at this time.  Please opt for simpler code.

This is needed as the writer should satisfy the body-writer concept.
The body writer requires the parameterised constructor otherwise 
the concept check will fail.

> This is needed as the writer should satisfy the body-writer concept.
> The body writer requires the parameterised constructor otherwise 
> the concept check will fail.

I've done what I've asked before and the concept check has worked.  Templates were not required.  Can you post the code you tried somewhere?

See the issue below 
https://godbolt.org/z/E7rdEcjaq

The usage of boost::beast::http::message_generator is the problem.

ACK.  Just take out the isRequest template param.  It's not clear to me why what you tried isn't working, but we can follow that up later.

Having every compile unit compile a template makes our compile times worse than they already are, but I guess we just have to deal with it and fix it later.

we cannot remove isRequest as well. The writer concept check checks for writer constructor for both true and false values. 
We can remove the template by duplicating the constructor code for both true and false. But I don't see any benefit in doing that.
Done
Please don't use auto in this way.  Looking at this code (and as an expert) I have no idea what this type is, so it's unlikely others will either.
Ack
Same here.

This does doesn't look like it works for more than one chunk.  Base64 has trailing characters for mod N sizes.  I suspect you need to use a base64 implementation that can track state.  This is chunking each base64 as its own chunk.
Ack
Ack
Boost types should not show up in the public API for this class.  I suspect you just want to make this set the body type directly.
The reasons for this are documented in HEADERS.md
Ack
Why are we seeking to 0?
Do we need to declare this if we don't use it?
yes, it is a forward declaration for the custom definition below.
see comment above.
common error (need to use the return code version).
this is not the naming convention the project uses.
Ack
Done
lets call this "file body".  It's not really a base anymore.
Ack
Done
Ignored error code.
Do you mean we should handle the error here? The caller will handle it anyway, right?

This code possibly has an error, then ignores it and continues on as if the error didn't happen.  If you want the user to handle it, you need something like 

if (ec) return;
This is going to force a full copy of every byte of data.  Is there any way to avoid this?
Answered above.  In theory the incremental base64 encoder will avoid the copy for most things;  At most it copies 2 bytes per chunk.
Ack
Done
Typo
Ack
Done
now that we're using our own encoding function, can we just update base64encode to support an incremental version, so we can avoid all the data copying and storage requirements?
Posted above.
Ack

lets get the naming better here.  We're not opening a base64 file, we're encoding the file after with base64.

This function doesn't look used.  Do we intend to use it somewhere?
this is API for completeness. In case future someone wants to open with path and wants to encode then they can use it.
Lets remove it then.  When someone has a use case for it, we can add it back, but at the moment it's dead code.
I suspect we can just construct this in place, instead of having a variable on stack that we move?
I believe I tried it before. We should set the native handle and no constructor helps.

as per our discussion, both bmc & system dump requires base64 encoding
please modify this commit message as well
Nope. Only the system dump uses base64 encoding. BMC dump will use plain text for backward compatibility.
why is this calculation needed here to get size of body.

what's the significance of %3 here?
please add a comment here
does this mean seek() here tries to set file size?
unfortunately yes. That is how we can support file reading using a descriptor.

Can't we just assume that the descriptor sent here has started at 0?  Not all descriptors support seeking, so this might be a dangerous operation.

If a seek is truly required, I'd much rather it be put in the code calling this API, so it can document in comments why it's required.  I wouldn't expect it to be required for any dbus calls.

It is not about just seeking. Unfortunately, the body type's size field will be initialized with this call. With an un-initialised size variable, the serializer doesn't work. Ideally, the native_handle set call should take care of the size also.
the body size field will be initialized with prepare-payload, right?
need similar max size check?
nope. In the file body case, the max chunk is defined to be 4k. So there is no chance of using higher memory. And we have a timeout in place for aborting large file offloads.

what's the error returned while aborting large dump offloads?
what's the max dump size offloaded in your testing?
I was thinking if we can avoid hitting this timeout by keeping nominal max dump size that can be offloaded with in this timeout.

we cannot do that. The maximum size will be subjective. It depends on the network speed. We may be able to offload a 100MB file in the test setup but that does not mean that it will work in production environment. The clients will get same connection terminated error as they get for other timouts.

agreed, in case of slow network even 5MB dump may not able to offload.
what's the error returned while aborting dump offloads when timeout hit?
const reference?

I'd like to see us break up the file body state handling from the base64 handling.  Could you please take a look at this, and see if it works for you?  If so, just pull the code into your PR please, and get some unit tests written.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/68267
Sorry, I meant this one.  Technically this is incorrect to use the file_body here, as we should be decoding base64.  I suspect we can just remove it?
please use using here.

Lets retain this check for the moment.  If we want to remove it, lets have that discussion in a different patchset, after this optimization has landed and we know it works.

Generally splitting up patchsets that intend to change behavior is a good idea.
Acknowledged

Why do we need a generator callback here?  I suspect this api can just accept a std::string_view for the content?

I see one place where we use this callback with non static data, and that just generates a std::string.  Is suspect we cam make this simpler.
several coding standard violations here.  Please take a pass at simplifying this code block, and once you've gone through that, we can start address individual issues.
wanted to collect data from the buffer sequence. Since it is accumulating data from a buffer sequence, I used std::accumulate. Are you suggesting replacing it with a for loop?
If you think that would make this block easier to read.  as is, it's tough to read, so take your first pass at making it easier to read, and we can go from there.

Can we use something like https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_83_0/libs/beast/doc/html/beast/ref/boost__beast__file_posix.html

so that we get RAII cleanup, instead of having to call fclose?
Why fileno on all of these?
